title: How to Make a Bed or Home for Your Stuffed Animal

steps.headline: Find an unused box.
steps.description: It should be slightly longer and wider than your companion. Shoe boxes work very well for small toys, but bigger ones will need bigger boxes. If you're making a house, it's better to use a much bigger box than your companion. If you're using a colored box, remember that this will be the exterior color of the house. The picture shows a great example of a nice bed that fits a sock monkey very well.

steps.headline: Put a blanket inside the box.
steps.description: This will be the carpet. Be creative! Having a gray carpet isn't very nice. Try adding some patterns. You can also try making it with the color of your walls.

steps.headline: Add some house-like features to it.
steps.description: Windows, chimneys, and doors are wonderful choices. If you're confused, have a look around your own house!

steps.headline: Add some furnishings.
steps.description: You wouldn't want to live in a house with nothing but a window and a carpet, would you? If your stuffed animal is a monkey, you might try adding some rocks and branches so it can climb on. Or if it's more of the human-animal kind, furniture is good. You can try adding in some mini couches, beds, tables and more. Getting these things are quite easy - you can get them from a Barbie set or make them with some guides here at wikiHow.

steps.headline: Decorate the outside of your box.
steps.description: You might try adding a removable rooftop, a basement, or even some mini garden hoses and a porch! Be creative!

steps.headline: Place the finished house in the desired location.
steps.description: You could put the house in your bedroom, in the kitchen, or even in the bathroom!

steps.headline: Cut off all of the flaps on the box.
Get both of the longer flaps and adhere them to the bottom of the box to make the bottom flat (if it already is, skip this step)
Grab one of the smaller flaps of the box and adhere it to the bottom of the box so it can be used to prop up the bed.
Find a thick fabric to place at the bottom of the box.
Find something to use as a pillow.
steps.description: You can cut out a piece of fabric and put some cotton balls in it, and tape the fabric closed.

steps.headline: Place your stuffed friend in the bed.
steps.description: You could even cut out some openings in the bottom to use as storage.

steps.description: If you are using a tissue box, get something to cover the hole. However, do not glue it there, since the hole is useful.

steps.headline: Get a piece of fabric, paper, or even a tissue to put on the box.
steps.description: Put it on top of the box and glue it on. Teddy wouldn't want to sleep on the cold mattress!

steps.headline: Get another piece of fabric or tissue as a blanket.
To make storage space, cut a hole in the side of the box.

text: Making a House Find an unused box. It should be slightly longer and wider than your companion. Shoe boxes work very well for small toys, but bigger ones will need bigger boxes. If you're making a house, it's better to use a much bigger box than your companion. If you're using a colored box, remember that this will be the exterior color of the house. The picture shows a great example of a nice bed that fits a sock monkey very well. Put a blanket inside the box. This will be the carpet. Be creative! Having a gray carpet isn't very nice. Try adding some patterns. You can also try making it with the color of your walls. Add some house-like features to it. Windows, chimneys, and doors are wonderful choices. If you're confused, have a look around your own house! Add some furnishings. You wouldn't want to live in a house with nothing but a window and a carpet, would you? If your stuffed animal is a monkey, you might try adding some rocks and branches so it can climb on. Or if it's more of the human-animal kind, furniture is good. You can try adding in some mini couches, beds, tables and more. Getting these things are quite easy - you can get them from a Barbie set or make them with some guides here at wikiHow. Decorate the outside of your box. You might try adding a removable rooftop, a basement, or even some mini garden hoses and a porch! Be creative! Place the finished house in the desired location. You could put the house in your bedroom, in the kitchen, or even in the bathroom! Making a Large, Cozy Bed Find a box that is slightly longer and wider than your companion. A box slightly larger than a shoebox will work. Cut off all of the flaps on the box.  Get both of the longer flaps and adhere them to the bottom of the box to make the bottom flat (if it already is, skip this step)  Grab one of the smaller flaps of the box and adhere it to the bottom of the box so it can be used to prop up the bed.  Find a thick fabric to place at the bottom of the box. This will be the mattress. Find something to use as a pillow. You can cut out a piece of fabric and put some cotton balls in it, and tape the fabric closed. Place your stuffed friend in the bed. You could even cut out some openings in the bottom to use as storage. Finished.  Making a Small, Simple Bed Get a box. If you are using a tissue box, get something to cover the hole. However, do not glue it there, since the hole is useful. Get a piece of fabric, paper, or even a tissue to put on the box. Put it on top of the box and glue it on. Teddy wouldn't want to sleep on the cold mattress! Get another piece of fabric or tissue as a blanket.  To make storage space, cut a hole in the side of the box. If you have a tissue box, just use the hole that's already there. Finished.
